How Much Salt Should I Have Each Day? Tweet Feb 21, 2011 James Cooper 0 Comments Join the Conversation One Cup of Soup Can Be Too Much Sodium - (c)J Cooper The newest recommendations for daily salt (sodium) intake are startlingly low. For half the US, one cup of soup fills the goal; any more salt is excessive. Watching the cook pour salt on the French fries at a fast food restaurant, one can see how Americans have come to consume more salt per person than ever before, and more per person than many other industrialized countries. Experts say the high salt intake contributes directly to stroke, heart attack and heart failure risk. Also, Americans like salty foods (chips, fries, popcorn, hot dogs) and with the salt comes high calories, contributing to overweight and obesity.
Americans like the taste of salt, but don't need much salt. To be specific, we are talking about sodium. Table salt is sodium chloride, and is the major source of sodium in most cultures.
New Sodium Guidelines
The US Department of Agriculture and Department of Health and Human Services put together a panel of experts to make recommendations about daily dietary intake. Sodium was one of the topics. The most important recommendations had to do with upper limits of sodium intake—the"do not exceed"recommendations. The experts call these Tolerable Upper Intake Levels. The 2010 recommendations are:
1500 mg/day for African Americans, and people with high blood pressure, diabetes, kidney disease, and people age 51 and older. 2300 mg/day for all others ages 14 and older
The 1500 mg/day recommendation extends to almost half the US population, and is less than half the average intake of Americans today. Even more stringent levels may apply to people with certain clinical conditions.

Ways to Reduce Sodium Intake
Cutting back on salty French fries is one way to reduce sodium intake, but, perhaps surprisingly, the food types responsible for the most sodium intake are yeast breads, chicken dishes, pizza, and pasta. That's because they are consumed so often. Ways to reduce individual sodium intake include:
Lock up the salt shaker (or limit its use) Use more fresh vegetables (processing often includes adding sodium) Read product labels and select lower sodium foods Ask for low sodium dishes in restaurants Consume fewer calories; salt comes in breads, pizza, pasta dishes
How Much is Not Enough Sodium?
The experts couldn't produce a Recommended Daily (RDA) Allowance because minimum requirements are not known (what is the minimum amount of sodium needed for 98% of the population to prevent sodium deficiency disease?). Instead, they advised Adequate Intake levels, which are levels found in healthy people. These are the"at least this much"levels and take into account sweating (a major loss of sodium) by unacclimatized people working in a hot environment.
1000 mg/day ages 1 to3 years 1200 mg/day for ages 4 to 8 1500 mg/day for people ages 9 to 50 1300 mg/day for ages 51 to 70 1200 mg/day for ages 71 and older
